page.title: 01River Laver Valley & Hills
page.content: This is a country area typical of many such areas in Yorkshire. It includes one small village, Laverton which serves mainly as a focal point for roads meeting and passing through to the larger surrounding villages. It has no amenities other than a public telephone. Most of the land in this area is now farmed, but is only good enough for grazing, mostly sheep, as it is reclaimed moorland. The river Lamer meanders through the centre of this area, amply supplied from the surrounding hills. It runs through a steep sided valley at one end onto the flat, low area in which the village is found. The south of the area is still marshland. Centrally there is a large coniferous plantation and several smaller ones - both coniferous and deciduous. It has a good road network serving all the hillside farms.
